4.56.text: These people are amongst the greatest quiz players in Britain.

9.88.text: Together they make up the Eggheads -

12.20.text: arguably the most formidable quiz team in the country.

17.44.text: The question is - can they be beaten?

23.40.text: Welcome to Eggheads - the show where a team of five quiz Challengers

27.20.text: pit their wits against possibly the greatest quiz team in Britain.

30.52.text: They are the Eggheads, and I don't even know why I say possibly. You clearly are, aren't you?

34.60.text: Hostage to fortune if you say that, Jeremy.

36.88.text: Look at them very quietly saying, "Yes, we are."

39.72.text: Taking on the awesome might of the Eggheads today

44.88.text: This team of colleagues all work for the same youth charity

47.88.text:
- based in the New Forest. Let's meet them. 
- Hi. I'm Chris.

54.08.text: Hi. I'm Alice. I'm a PR and social media officer.

58.68.text: Hi, I'm Dulcie and I'm a lead youth officer.

61.40.text: Hi, I'm Jan and I'm a youth services manager.

64.12.text:
- Hi, I'm Kat and I'm a youth advisor. 
- So, Chris, team, welcome. 
- Thank you.

68.52.text: Good to see you. The youth charity is called what?

72.04.text: It's called It's Your Choice. It's been around for 28 years.

75.60.text: We support around 3,500 young people a year who live

79.40.text: in and around the New Forest on issues like homelessness

82.96.text: and mental health, supporting young people into education,

88.40.text: Some young people have issues with substance misuse.

93.04.text: Whatever they need, we give them support with that.

95.44.text: I'm thinking this is right up your street, CJ. The sort of thing you support.

98.92.text: It's the sort of work I am very much involved with.

101.52.text: Especially homelessness. That's an absolute passion of mine.

104.96.text:
- It's a huge problem where we work. 
- And tell me about the quizzing.

108.68.text: At what point do you get together, put all that to one side and have a serious quiz?

113.88.text: We've quizzed individually, but not as a team,

117.20.text: so we're starting right at the top.

120.08.text: You've come together today as individual quizzers to make a team.

124.48.text:
- That's correct. 
- Well, good luck against the Eggheads.

127.76.text: Every day there is £1,000 of cash up for grabs for our Challengers.

130.92.text: However, if they fail to defeat the Eggheads,

133.72.text: that prize money rolls over to our next show. Now, Right Choice,

137.56.text: I can tell you the Eggheads are on one heck of a roll.

141.00.text:
- They've won the last 23 games. 
- Wow!

143.72.text: But you know what that means.

147.88.text: That's the money that says you can't beat them.

150.60.text: I'd love you to do it. Mustn't say that.

152.96.text: The first head-to-head battle is on the subject of Geography.

155.96.text:
- Who would like this? 
- Who's going to take Geography, guys?

159.12.text:
- Isn't that you, Kat? 
- That's me, isn't it?

164.20.text: Against which Egghead? Any one of the five.

166.24.text:
- Let's see if we can peel them apart. 
- Who's good at Geography?

169.72.text:
- Do you want to go for Barry? 
- That's fine. 
- Try Barry. 
- Take Barry.

174.12.text:
- We'll go for Barry, please, Jeremy. 
- OK.

176.48.text: So, Kat from Right Choice versus Barry from the Eggheads.

179.68.text: Any questions on Japan, Barry likes. There the whole time, aren't you?

184.88.text: To ensure there's no conferring, would you please

187.60.text: take your positions in our Question Room?

190.48.text:
- So, you travel a bit, Kat? 
- Yeah. Try to.

194.60.text:
- I gather not so much in your own car? 
- No. Not at the moment anyway.

200.72.text:
- How is the driving test going? 
- It's going OK. I'm persisting, at best.

206.20.text: Sensitively, tell us how many times you've failed.

209.32.text:
- I think we're up to number 17 and we're still going. 
- OK.

212.60.text: And the failures, are they all for the same reason?

216.28.text:
- Like you reverse instead of driving forward? 
- No, various reasons.

222.24.text: You know. I've done numerous things.

225.40.text: I've driven into things, I've closed my eyes when a lorry went past.

228.52.text: It's just not good. I'm going to get a horse.

230.92.text: There was somebody in the area my parents live who...

233.80.text: The examiner fell out of the car when they were taking a corner.

237.24.text: I haven't done that yet, so, I mean... There's time.

240.04.text:
- One for your bucket list. Good luck. I hope you pass soon. 
- Thank you.

244.08.text: And here we are on Geography against Barry.

247.08.text:
- Would you like to go first or second? 
- First, please.

253.08.text: Here is your question, Kat. Good luck.

255.36.text: The US state of Florida is bordered by which ocean?

262.20.text: I have been to Florida, but it's not jumping out at me.

266.12.text: I know it's not the Indian. I'm going to say Atlantic.

271.24.text: Atlantic is spot on. Well done. Well done. Barry, your question.

275.52.text: Which French city is known as the capital of the Alps?

282.92.text: I think, the capital of the Alps, it must be Grenoble.

294.64.text: The town of Beaumaris lies at the north-eastern end

304.52.text: Erm... This is a difficult one. I think...

307.56.text: I don't think it's the Solent cos that's near me

309.68.text: and I certainly haven't heard that term. Erm...

315.28.text: I'm going to go with the Menai Strait.

318.80.text:
- The Menai Strait is the right answer. 
- OK.

323.56.text: Which of these Australian states shares a border

338.80.text: I think Queensland is separated by Northern Territories

342.04.text: from Western Australia, so I think it must be South Australia.

345.12.text:
- Well done, Barry. Is that on your list? Or have you been there? 
- No.

347.88.text: It's very much on my list, is Australia.

351.96.text: Many Australian friends and I'd love to visit them.

354.40.text: Because Eggheads is played there, isn't it?

356.64.text:
- So you might get recognised. 
- It is. Big hit over there. We're popular.

360.80.text: Would you bring your stand along which says "Meet Barry Simmons"

363.76.text:
- if you went to Australia? 
- No. I'd bring my wife, Jeremy.

369.56.text: OK. Kat. Abidjan is a chief port in which country?

384.68.text: I think I'd go for Cameroon.

388.36.text:
- Cos it's a bit French sounding. 
- Ah-ha.

391.80.text:
- It is Cote d'Ivoire, as a matter of fact. 
- Oh, no.

395.12.text: A chance for Barry to take the round on the third question.

398.20.text: The Shinano River, which for part of its length is also known

401.80.text: as the Chikuma River, is the longest river in which country?

411.40.text: but I think the longest river in Japan might be the Bifue.

415.12.text: I'm going to go for South Korea.

417.84.text: I was sort of saying earlier on, your best subject is what, Barry?

421.68.text:
- You're going to tell me it's Japan now, aren't you? 
- Yeah.

425.32.text: Your strongest bit of geography is Japan and it is Japan

429.00.text: and you got it wrong. How does that work?

431.36.text:
- I had another river in my mind for Japan. 
- So you're equal after three.

435.24.text: We go to Sudden Death. Kat.

437.68.text: The Great Slave Lake is a major lake on which continent?

444.56.text: It's actually in Canada, so it's North America.

450.32.text: The most easterly point on the Arabian peninsula is in which country?

454.92.text: The Arabian peninsula is roughly triangular

458.64.text: and the country in the north-east is Oman, so I'll go for Oman.

465.68.text: Can you visualise the map in your head as you say that?

468.08.text:
- Are you one of these... 
- Roughly, yes.

470.28.text: You've got an amazing facility there. Right. Well done.

473.32.text: Good quizzing. That's a tough question. Oman is right. Sorry, Kat.

476.32.text: On Sudden Death he's knocked you out and he will be in the final, not you.

480.32.text: Please return to us and we'll play on.

483.96.text: So, Right Choice are a brain down but plenty of time yet

487.72.text: and as members of a charity you are always hopeful and optimistic about the future.

492.12.text:
- We certainly are. 
- OK. The next subject for you

495.04.text: is Film and TV. Who'd like this?

497.08.text:
- It's got to be me. 
- Is it Dulcie? 
- Yeah.

500.16.text: Who do you want to play against, Dulcie?

502.52.text:
- Did you want to go against Chris? 
- Chris? 
- Yeah, I think so. 
- OK.

506.12.text:
- So it's going to be Dulcie against Chris. 
- Dulcie, OK, in the middle.

510.76.text: On Film and TV. From Right Choice. Versus Chris from the Eggheads.

514.56.text: To ensure there's no conferring, would you please

517.04.text: take your positions in our Question Room?

520.68.text: So, Dulcie, what's your preferred Film and TV?

523.92.text: I quite like horror, so I watch quite a lot of horror films.

529.32.text: I love horror but my wife won't let me watch it unless I'm on my own.

534.16.text: Have you got a partner who can actually enjoy it with you?

537.20.text: Yeah, my husband. He will watch horror with me.

540.44.text:
- He's not a great fan but he's not a baby about it. 
- It's Film and TV.

545.52.text: Would you like to go first or second?

547.60.text: I think I'll go first, please.

555.40.text: Which of these films was originally released in the 1940s?

569.16.text: So it means they were obviously done again

572.12.text: cos I think of them all as being done later.

577.80.text: I don't think it would be Dr No.

581.40.text: So I'm torn between Breakfast at Tiffany's or Citizen Kane.

585.36.text: Erm... It's a bit of a guess.

588.96.text: I'm going to go with Citizen Kane.

591.80.text: Brilliant. You got it. Well done. Citizen Kane it is.

598.92.text: Which show, regularly presented by Chris Evans,

602.76.text: returned for a one-off special in June 2015?

614.76.text: Now, most iconic of those and the one most likely to

617.60.text:
- return for a one-off special is The Big Breakfast. 
- OK.

621.48.text:
- It's wrong, I'm afraid. It was TFI Friday. 
- Oh.

625.68.text: OK, back to you, Dulcie. This is good. You're in the lead.

630.32.text: In which year was the UK TV game show Family Fortunes first broadcast?

643.20.text: Was it Les Dennis? Did he do the hosting of it?

649.00.text: Was it him? Is that the right show? Family Fortunes? Erm...

656.36.text: I'm going to go with - cos it's a bit of a guess -

667.08.text: OK, well done, Dulcie. Playing well here. Chris is on the ropes.

671.00.text: Which 2010 animated film features the three orphan girls,

683.20.text: They're the three rather sweet little girls in Despicable Me.

686.88.text: Despicable Me is the right answer. Well done. You saw it...

689.56.text:
- You didn't see it at the cinema, did you? 
- Oh, no.

692.28.text: Cos you don't go to the cinema.

694.80.text: Dulcie. What is the first name of the actress who

697.92.text: appeared in Martha Marcy May Marlene and Avengers: Age of Ultron,

703.20.text: who is the younger sister of Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen?

711.96.text: This is really hard because I remember seeing something

715.16.text: written about her and now I'm trying to remember what her name is.

721.44.text: I think for some reason Elizabeth seems to be ringing a bell

728.16.text: so I'm going to go with Elizabeth.

730.68.text: You've got it bang on. Well done.

733.48.text: And you've got three out of three, so Dulcie, well done.

736.48.text: You've knocked Chris out. There's no way back for him.

738.80.text: His wrong answer has been fatal. He will not be in the final. You will.

742.56.text: Come back and we'll see what happens next.

746.08.text: So, as it stands, Right Choice have lost one brain from the final round.

749.48.text: The Eggheads have lost one as well. Well played, Dulcie.

752.28.text: Let's see what happens next. It's Politics. Who's the politician?

755.88.text: Well, I think that's going to be Jan. Yep.

761.88.text:
- Up against CJ? 
- CJ? 
- Yeah, go on. Let's have CJ.

765.16.text: Jan will go up against CJ, Jeremy.

767.56.text: Jan from Right Choice versus CJ from the Eggheads. He's like, yep!

770.84.text:
- Happy with that? 
- Happy with Politics. 
- You do like your Politics.

776.04.text: please take your positions in the Question Room.

778.96.text: So, we are on Politics. Jan, would you like to go first or second?

782.56.text: I'd like to go second, please.

788.96.text: Which of these is one of the currencies

798.04.text: Well, I think the shekel is Israel and the baht is Thailand.

802.48.text: The escudo is Portugal which I think is in Europe so I'll try the escudo.

807.96.text: Portugal is definitely in Europe. Escudo is the right answer.

813.88.text: In which year did journalist Martin Bell famously defeat Neil Hamilton

817.84.text: in the general election to become the MP for Tatton?

827.92.text: Just trying to think whether it would be as early as 1983.

834.80.text: Or whether actually it was a bit later.

838.32.text: I'm going to go down the middle. 1997. I think it was a bit later.

844.80.text: It was the first year of the Tony Blair landslide. OK, CJ.

848.68.text: What is the name of the official residence

850.68.text: of the Speaker of the House of Commons?

858.56.text: This is one of those where I've heard of one of those answers...

865.08.text: ..and I'm just wondering if I've heard it because it's

868.00.text: the answer to the question or it's just something else.

874.60.text: I'm sure I've heard of Speaker's Lodge.

877.68.text: But have I heard of Speaker's House?

881.72.text: If it is Speaker's House, I apologise because it is nagging me

884.88.text: but I have to go with my first instinct, which was Speaker's Lodge.

888.36.text: Yes, it's a tricky old question, this.

890.68.text: Not mentioned that much, although they had a bit of a refurb

893.56.text: so it came into the news.

895.40.text: The refurbishment was done in Speaker's House. CJ.

898.80.text: Speaker's House. It was nagging you for a reason.

905.84.text: Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, third Marquis of Salisbury,

910.28.text: first became British Prime Minister in which year?

918.32.text: Robert Gascoyne-Cecil? Not a name that I know.

930.36.text:
- OK. And this gentleman was known as Lord Salisbury, was he not? 
- Yep.

933.36.text:
- And is she right? 
- No. 
- No.

941.24.text: You're level, one point each. Third question. CJ?

944.08.text: The Bishop of Urgell is one of the two co-princes of which country?

956.24.text: Again, not a name I've heard of.

958.80.text: But I can't imagine it's Monaco.

960.88.text: That's... Surely the Grimaldis have got that all tied up?

964.64.text: Just going on the language more than anything else, I mean, Andorra?

971.68.text: I mean, the name obviously sounds more French.

978.04.text: Has Andorra got princes? I don't know.

980.76.text: But I think Luxembourg does have princes as well as a government.

986.40.text: And, certainly, the language is leading me towards Luxembourg

989.92.text: rather than the other two. So, I will try Luxembourg.

993.44.text: OK, Barry, I'm going to ask you for this answer.

997.68.text: the Bishop of Urgell, and the French President.

1000.76.text:
- Ah, I see. And Luxembourg, no? 
- No. 
- The Grand Duke.

1004.52.text: Grand Duke, Luxembourg has a Grand Duke.

1006.48.text: And Andorra has two co-princes, Barry says.

1012.24.text:
- One is this fella. And then the President of France. 
- Yes.

1015.40.text: Sorry, CJ, you got it wrong.

1017.48.text: Jen. Your third question, get this right, you're in the final.

1023.44.text: Which politician told the BBC that he would eat his hat

1026.84.text: if the exit polls for the 2015 general election were right?

1035.88.text: I actually know the answer to this one, I saw him on television,

1039.44.text: on election night. And, yeah, it's Paddy Ashdown.

1044.28.text: But I haven't actually seen him eat his hat yet.

1046.60.text: JEREMY LAUGHS So, you were watching the programme?

1051.52.text:
- It was an interesting night. 
- Yeah, it was amazing.

1054.76.text: And we were sweating on the exit poll, that's for sure.

1057.08.text: But it turned out to be right because the guy who did it

1059.36.text: was a bit of a genius, John Curtice.

1061.00.text: So, it was Paddy Ashdown who had to eat his hat.

1065.40.text: I think, on the matter of the hat,

1067.40.text: somebody made him a chocolate cake in a hat shape, and he ate that.

1073.96.text: You never quite get what was promised.

1078.52.text: Sorry, CJ. Sin-bin for you. Jan's in the final.

1080.80.text: The Challengers are winning, and there's a lot of money to play for.

1084.04.text: Please come back, we'll get on with it.

1087.76.text: It's looking rather good for Right Choice.

1089.80.text: They've lost a brain from the final round.

1091.76.text: But they have taken out two Egghead brains.

1093.84.text: The Eggheads started with this little bit of jaunty swagger.

1098.28.text: You can see the fear in their eyes now.

1103.92.text:
- It's got to be you. 
- Got to be you, Alice.

1107.08.text:
- Who are we going to have? 
- Alice? OK.

1109.48.text: And you can have either Judith or Kevin,

1111.40.text:
- so, one of the two on the right. 
- I think we'll go for Judith.

1113.96.text:
- I think we'll go for Judith, please, Jeremy.

1116.80.text: Alice, from Right Choice, versus Judith from the Eggheads, on Music.

1144.44.text: I want to say that they all died quite young, maybe. Um...

1161.08.text:
- Buddy Holly.

1170.64.text:
- '71 he died.

- UNDER HER BREATH

1241.48.text: It is Kanye West. Well done, yeah, absolutely.

1258.72.text: I'm going to say Little Mix.

1262.40.text: Well, it was an instinct, actually.

1266.52.text: two to the Eggheads, one to our challenger.

1287.28.text: I'm going to go straight down the middle again, I think Manchester.

1293.32.text: quite a good reputation for music. So, Manchester.

1297.32.text: Yeah, it is Manchester. Good stuff. Got it right.

1303.24.text: because of Alice's wrong answer earlier.

1327.80.text: you are in the final round.

- Written by McCartney, I think.

- It was a good guess.

1518.24.text:
- I don't know.

- Do you think it is?

1532.00.text: I don't know. Victorian name, is it?

1533.56.text: We have to give an answer, so let's...

1535.72.text: Shall we go for...? You came in at Robert, Jan, or shall we?

1540.16.text:
- We've got too much pressure. 
- No?

1541.88.text:
- We'll go for it, yeah. 
- Go for it.

1543.40.text: We don't really know this, Jeremy,

1545.12.text: but we think we're going to take a stab at Robert.

1550.00.text: Third question, here. Let's see if the Eggheads know. Do you know?

1558.00.text: OK, Eggheads, here we are again.

1559.68.text: You have matters in your hands now.

1562.04.text: If you get this right, the contest is over.

1564.24.text: Which daughter of Queen Victoria was the mother of Alexandra Feodorovna,

1569.12.text: the wife of Tsar Nicholas II?

1575.36.text:
- I don't know, straight off. 
- No. Um...

1579.00.text: OK, let's think who they all married. Um...

1590.96.text:
- Was she? 
- Alexandra of Hesse... Alexandra of...

1593.32.text: The one who married Nicholas II,

1594.84.text:
- so Queen Victoria's granddaughter, she... 
- Yes.

1597.08.text:
- I think she was the Princess of Hesse, or "Hess-e." 
- Was she?

1603.32.text: Who married the Prince of Hesse?

1605.68.text: I... I don't know why, I'm having a sort of blip.

1608.68.text:
- I have an inkling for Alice but I don't know why. 
- Yes, so do I.

1611.44.text: I have an inkling for Alice.

1614.84.text: Isn't she the one who married the Duke of Cornwall?

1618.56.text: She was one of the younger ones, wasn't she?

1622.40.text: um, Alexandra and Nicholas were already...

1626.92.text:
- you know, obviously, married, then. 
- Mm-hmm. 
- That was 1894,

1630.44.text: when he came to the throne,

1632.60.text:
- so it's got to be one of the older daughters. 
- Yeah.

1635.72.text: My instinct is Alice, but I've no great...

1637.64.text:
- My instinct is Alice too. 
- Well, my instinct...

1639.72.text: The three of our instincts are Alice, which...

1641.80.text: Yeah, I've no great confidence in it, but...

1643.72.text: Does three instincts make an inkling?

1646.12.text:
- I think, on balance, we all have an instinct for Alice. 
- Yeah.

1649.76.text: We've got an instinct for Alice. OK.

1651.68.text:
- All of us. 
- I mean it could be...

1653.28.text:
- It could be because Alexandra was known as "Alix"... 
- Alix of Hesse.

1656.12.text: ..so we could be being fooled by that, but we're not sure, basically.

1660.72.text: We should know this, but we don't think it's Louise.

1665.64.text: A little bit of a problem with the other two,

1668.88.text: but, on balance, we'll go for Alice.

1676.76.text: You have got it right. The answer is Alice.

1679.08.text: Well done, Eggheads, we say congratulations. You've won again.

1687.44.text: Always fascinating, when they have to work their way to it.

1692.56.text: They won on a difficult question

1694.04.text: and they've done what comes naturally to them.

1697.96.text: so it does mean you won't be going home with the £24,000.

1700.60.text: The money rolls over to our next show. Eggheads, well done.

1705.88.text: but there are just moments when I wonder.

1708.68.text: Join us next time to see if a new team of Challengers

1711.68.text: will have the brains to defeat them and win £25,000.
